metadata.case_name: Santosh Kumar and Northern General Agencies v. Plaintiff

facts.text: Plaintiff filed suit in Court of Commercial Subordinate Judge, Delhi, under Order XXXVII CPC on basis of cheque for Rs. 60,000 drawn by defendants in favour of plaintiff, which was dishonoured on presentation to Bank.

Defendants admitted execution of the cheque but pleaded it was given only as collateral security for price of goods supplied by plaintiff to defendants, and that goods were paid for by cash payments from time to time and by other cheques, so cheque in suit had served its end and should be returned.
Defendants set out exact dates on which payments were made and numbers of the cheques in their affidavit.
Defendants applied for leave to defend suit under r.3 of Order XXXVII.
Trial Judge held defence raises triable issue but defendants placed nothing on file to show defence bona fide; permitted defence on condition of giving security for suit amount and costs.
Defendants applied for review before trial Judge and failed.
Defendants applied under Art. 227 Constitution to Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi and failed.
Defendants granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether leave to defend under Order XXXVII r.3 CPC should be granted unconditionally when defence raises triable issue, or conditions can be imposed even if bona fides not disproved.
Scope of discretion under Order XXXVII r.3(2) to impose conditions like security for leave to defend.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defence raises triable issue as facts in affidavit, if proved, provide good defence; leave must be unconditional if triable issue raised.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Order XXXVII r.3(1) CPC; triable issue test from Jacobs v. Booths Distillery Company

respondent_arguments.text: Discretion under r.3(2) unfettered; no appeal lies unless grave miscarriage of justice; trial Judge exercised discretion properly.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: D.N. Banerji v. P.R. Mukherjee; Waryam Singh v. Amarnath

respondent_arguments.text: Defence not bona fide as no documents produced to support assertions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Gopala Rao v. Subba Rao; Manohar Lal v. Nanhe Mal; Shib Karan Das v. Mohammed Sadiq

court_reasoning.text: Procedural laws to facilitate justice, not frustrate; construed in light of natural justice principles that men not condemned unheard.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules of procedure grounded on natural justice.

court_reasoning.text: If defence raises triable issue, leave must be given unconditionally; conditions only if not bona fide, but cannot conclude not bona fide arbitrarily without proof stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Triable issue test: if facts alleged, if proved, good/plausible defence.

court_reasoning.text: Trial Judge erred: defence clear and precise on face; no need to produce evidence before leave granted; stage of proof after leave.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defence not vague; facts specific with dates and cheque numbers.

court_reasoning.text: Discretion exercised arbitrarily based on misunderstanding; interference warranted as failure of justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conditions only to ensure speedy trial if prolongation suspected, not merely for lack of pre-leave evidence.

holdings.text: Court must grant unconditional leave to defend if affidavit discloses facts making triable issue; discretion judicial, not arbitrary.
Conditions imposable only if defence not bona fide or to prevent prolongation; here, triable issue raised unconditionally.

precedents_cited.case_name: D. N. Banerji v. P.R. Mukherjee
precedents_cited.relevance: No appeal against discretion unless grave miscarriage.
No appeal against discretion unless grave miscarriage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sangram Singh v. Election Tribunal, Kotah
precedents_cited.relevance: Procedural laws facilitate justice; interpret with elasticity and natural justice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Powszechny Bank Zwiazkowy W. Polsce v. Paros
precedents_cited.relevance: Leave unconditional if triable issue, else illusory.
Triable issue test; object to prevent frivolous defences.
Court may impose conditions if not bona fide.
Court may impose conditions if not bona fide.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shib Karan Das v. Mohammed Sadiq
precedents_cited.relevance: Court may impose conditions if not bona fide.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kesavan v. South Indian Bank Ltd.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs summary suits on bills/cheques; leave to defend conditional or unconditional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court supervisory jurisdiction; Supreme Court special leave.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of High Court and trial Judge set aside; case remanded to trial court for trial of issues raised by defendants.
outcome.relief_granted: Unconditional leave to defend implied by remand for full trial.

key_quotes.text: "A code of procedure must be regarded as such. It is procedure, something designed to facilitate justice and further its ends not a penal enactment for punishment and penalties; not a thing designed to trip people up."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle for interpreting procedural rules like Order XXXVII.

key_quotes.text: "our laws of procedure are grounded on a principle of natural justice which requires that men should not be condemned unheard"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies unconditional leave if triable issue to uphold natural justice.

key_quotes.text: "the test is to see whether the defence raises a real issue and not a sham one, in the sense that, if the facts alleged by the defendant are established, there would be a good, or even a plausible, defence on those facts."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines triable issue test for granting leave.
